captions.text:
Hey guys, ChrisFix here, today I am going
to show you how to tell if your tie rods have gone bad

A bad tie rod can cause uneven tire
wear and if it is really bad, it can even

disconnect while you are driving, and that
is just a bad situation.

Besides tire wear, bad tie rods can cause a clunky feel when
you first turn your steering wheel.

It can also squeak when when you use the steering wheel but that can also be a ball joint, so you 
have to go and check it out.

If you have any
of these symptoms just jack up the front 
of the car and I will show you how to test it.
With both tires off the ground
what you are going to  want to do is put your hands at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions on the wheel.
With your hands in those positions, move them back and forth and see if there is any play in the wheel.
You will feel a clicking or a giving movement
And that movement could indicate a bad tie rod.
If you think there is some play or you just want to check further, you can take the tire off and inspect the tie rod itself.
There are two parts to your tie rods
Your inner tie rod,
and your outer tie rod.
Inspect the inner tie rod visually by looking at the boot and seeing if there are any leaks.
I dont see any leaks here... The boot is still intact.
There are no holes or rips
So that looks good.
Now for the outer tie rod, you can see here already,
There is a nice big gash on my tie rod boot.
and this just happens over time.
The boot cracks and goes bad.
And inside you can see the grittiness.
And that grittiness is not good. That is sand and road grime that gets kicked up and
and goes in here... So this is bad.
If you catch a boot that was just recently torn
sometimes these boots are replaceable.
So you can just take the boot off and put a new one on.
And then you save yourself a lot of money
You dont have to do anything special, you dont have to get an alignment.
But if the boot has been ripped for a while and you see grit in there
then you are going to have to replace the whole tie rod end.
If your boot is good, then what you should do
is, you take the tie rod
and you try to move it left and right
move it, in and out
if there is any unwanted movement
or it clicks and you can easily move the tie rod from side to side
then it needs to be replaced.
now this is a new tie rod end
and this is what it should look like. Some tie rod ends
have a grease fitting
and that is what you want if you need to purchase a new one
and if you have a grease fitting
always grease this every time you do an oil change. It will force
the old grease out which carries all of the grit and sand.
so this will last a lot longer.
but upon visual inspection, you can see there are no
tares or gashes on the rubber
that covers the inner tie rod end.
Also, there is no unwanted movement like I was talking about before.
Obviously this is brand new,
but I need to give you an example to contrast the bad tie rod
now to test the tie rod even more
you can take it out
and you can see further that this boot is badly ripped and the grease is contaminated with grit.
The other thing is you can turn this with your hand and it feels gritty and clunky.
Which is not good, you want this to be smooth
So the outer tie rod is bad.
Now to test the inner tie rod, all you do is move this
in and out
and you want to feel for any clicking
if it clicks then the inner tie rod is bad.
Clicking indicates that the ball joint on the inner tie rod is worn out.
and it is allowing movement which isnt good. You dont want any movement in there!
This one is completely solid, which is good.
The other test you can do is move the tie rod around like this
and make sure there is no gritty feeling and no grinding.
It is fine if the tie rod is easy to move around
but it is bad if it move way too easily and feels way too loose.
This is relatively easy to move but I still feel some resistance, so that means this is still good.
So the outer tie rod is bad but the inner tie rod is good.
But that is fine because the outer tie rod is fixed easily.
and you can replace this in 10 minutes.
with no special tools
That video will be up on the screen
along with other videos, click the screen or find the link to those videos in the description below.
if this video was helpful,
if this video was helpful,
give it a "thumbs up"
also consider subscribing. I publish "how to" videos weekly
and I answer all of your questions and comments
check out the ChrisFix Facebook and Twitter pages with the link in the description.
If you check out your tie rod and have any questions, just leave a comment below and I will try to help you out.

title: How to Tell if Your Tie Rod is Bad

Please guys i need some advice here, when I turn my wheels all the way to 
the right (or left sometimes) it makes this popping sound like a clunk, I 
took it to Belle Tire but they're telling me they cannot diagnose the 
sound. I was like well whats up? Just ignore it? and the dude said 
everything looks perfectly fine and too just ride it out and if it gets 
worse to come back...? what do i do here? How can the car make this noise 
but everything be perfectly fine? What are your takes on this?﻿
comments.author: ReaLifeVideos420

comments.text:
+ReaLifeVideos420 That sounds like bushings might be worn on the control 
arm or maybe your tie rod needs some grease (if it is greasable). Does the 
noise happen at all when you hit a bump?

comments.text:
+ReaLifeVideos420 Does it only happen when you are moving or when you are 
stationary? Does it happen only when you turn the wheel all the way or when 
you turn the wheel more than 50% or when you turn the wheel just a little?

comments.author: shadad07

comments.text:
am planning to change the shocks anyway soon with Koni one. i will check 
these things on the same time. as for the rocking the mustang am GYM person 
and trust me i did my best and never heard clunks. i will check other stuff 
later. thanks for the advise.
comments.author: shadad07

comments.text:
+shadad07 Check your sway bar end links for play (wiggle them around and 
feel for clunks) and check the bushings that attache the sway bar to the 
body. Try rocking the mustang with your hands and listening for any clunks. 
That is a sign your body bushings or end links are bad.
comments.author: ChrisFix

is it related to the shock absorber  or what.?! the thing i took my car to 
a machanic and he says every thing look good. couple of my friends says its 
a sport car and it has to be stiff..but come on! if i step on any small 
bump even a little rock i can feel it. what do you think the cause ?
thanks again and keep up the good work.

comments.author: Abdullah orefan

comments.text:
+Abdullah orefan You probably have to use a tie rod puller or a pitman arm 
puller. Also, WD40 is not a penetrating fluid. Try this stuff:

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris, thanks heaps for the video! I kept hearing a clicking noise 
coming from my front left wheel which has been driving me nuts so I pulled 
the tyre off and had a look at the tie rod and found a fair bit of play in 
it (I could twist it around) - All other components are fine. Without this 
I wouldn't know where to start with diagnosis!﻿
comments.author: Nick Toffoli

comments.text:
+Nick Toffoli Ok good, so it sounds like you need end links or sway bar 
body bushings.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: +ChrisFix Ball joints are fine :)
comments.author: Nick Toffoli

comments.text:
+Nick Toffoli Gotcha. Clicking over bumps is typical of sway bar body 
bushings or end links. It could also be ball joints (less likely). Here is 
how to check ball joints: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62bVn7E8gyk
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix Its rear wheel drive - Toyota MR2. The clicking happens when 
driving when going over bumps. I suspected that it could be the sway bar 
links but seeing as I've replaced them all they've been taken out of the 
equation. The giveaway is that the boot has also split and there is a fair 
bunch of grit in there.
comments.author: Nick Toffoli

comments.text:
+Nick Toffoli The clicks could be the tie rod. Is your car front wheel 
drive? If so, it could be the CV axle making the noise. Does the clicking 
noise happen when you are driving?
comments.author: ChrisFix

one place. If it is 2wd, you dont have cv axles. I would try and listen to 
where the pop is coming from. Maybe have someone turn the car as you 
listen. I am guessing is is a u-joint now.

I just looked my truck doesn't have CV axles
﻿

﻿

comments.text: +Mark Kuhner It is the think that the axle nut screws into.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I have a f150 03 I just put 3.5 in
spindles an new lower ball joint an new A arm with balljoint an now wen I 
back up an turn to go forward something pops what is that﻿
comments.author: Mark Kuhner

comments.text:
+Mark Kuhner Yea, that really points to cv joints. When you did the knuckle 
upgrade, did you pull on the axle end? You might have separated it which is 
why it pops now.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
It does happen most often after I turn my wheel all the way then go back 
straight
comments.author: Mark Kuhner

comments.text:
Something is binding. Again, sounds like a possible cv joint problem but it 
could be something else. What happens if you shake the car so the 
suspension is bouncing around. Any clunking? Like go to the wheel well that 
has the pop and bounce the car around. Also, are you sure the noise is 
coming from the front? Did you check your drive shafts for play?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Like if I back out of a parking spot and turn the wheel one way then go 
straight and turn it back the other way that's when it pops
comments.author: Mark Kuhner

comments.text:
+Mark Kuhner Since you changed the suspension geometry it could be your cv 
joint making the popping noise. Does it make the noise with the tires 
turned all the way?
comments.author: ChrisFix

hi chris, do you have a video what show when a U joint or driveshaft is

work on a car with that problem!

comments.text:
Bit confused, my outers do not clunk or click no play in steering wheel, no 
tyre wear but the outer track rod ends on both sides  rock from side to 
side with a little firmness but still moveable by hand?? is this normal, or 
should the balljoint that goes through the Steering Knuckle be completely 
firm? another thing is the outers do not have  locking bolts to adjust the 
tracking, Ive had the car from new they have never been replaced and its 
done 72K miles. Its a  Japanese built CL7 Accord Euro/ TSX in US, is this 
normal to not have a locking/tracking bolt. Any thoughts?﻿

comments.text:
Hey Chris like your video s they are really helpful. I got a question my 
Honda accord wheel came came off while turning. The lug nuts were lose, the 
rotor did touch the ground and I drove 25 feet before I stop. I wanted to 
know before I get it fix I check the outer tie rod it move side to side but 
not much I was able to put the wheel on and it spin ok do you think I have 
change the tie rod. Sorry for writing to much.﻿
comments.author: antwonguz

comments.text:
+antwonguz I am glad my videos are helpful. The tie rod can move side to 
side but only a little. If it feels loose or clicks, then you need to 
replace it.
comments.author: ChrisFix

yes i checked my tie rods there all good i havent checked bushings,i

comments.text:
Got a question for you Chris. The front driver side of my jeep made a loud 
bang while reversing, and now when i turn the steering wheel i hear a loud 
clicking noise and something is rubbing against the power steering pump, 
any ideas of what that is ﻿

comments.author: Rich Young

9 times out of ten im thinking about replacing the tie rod front and end, 
cv joints, and getting an adjustable track bar...u think that would do it 
lol

comments.text: +Rich Young That sounds more like an axle problem. Like a bad cv joint.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: barely
comments.author: Rich Young

comments.text: Oh, so the front driver side tire wont even turn roll?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
yes only stationary/turning, when i do put it in gear only the back and 
right side wheels actually turn and i only noticed this when the jeep was 
towed
comments.author: Rich Young

comments.text:
+Rich Young Hm. I am thinking it is your rack and pinion then. So you can 
hear the clicking when you are stationary and turning the wheel? If there 
is clicking when you are moving/turning then I would think it might be a cv 
join assuming you have front wheel drive.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
thanks for your time chris...the pulley slows down a little but it does not 
stop rotating and the noise happens while rotaing either direction at a 
certain spot
comments.author: Rich Young

comments.text:
+Rich Young I just saw your other comment that your wheels barely move. 
When you turn the wheel, does the power steering pulley freeze or slow down?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+Rich Young Without seeing it, it will be hard to diagnose. Does the noise 
happen when the wheel is not being moved? Does it happen if you hold the 
wheel in a turn or only while you are turning it?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
my car wobbles left and right when going hitting bunps or going fast it 
wobbles a lot side to side what can it be??﻿
comments.author: mitsu93

comments.text:
+mitsu93 It can be the tie rods, ball joints, or worn out bushings. Have 
you checked your tie rods like in this video?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62bVn7E8gyk
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
A little off topic, but I'm hoping you might be able to point me in the 
right direction.  Have a bad wobble on the right front Saturn 2005 Ion. Old 
tire and a new tire.  Old tire wore out as if out of alignment.  Balance is 
good. No bearing noise.  What might be causing it?﻿
comments.author: Rob Wy

comments.text:
+Rob Wy That could be a bad tie rod (do the tests in this video) or a bad 
ball joint. Check out this video for the ball joint tests: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62bVn7E8gyk
I would start there and keep me posted on what you find!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:

left of it and also has a boot. Mine is squeaking right now and i don't 
know what to do about it.﻿
comments.author: Chase

comments.text: +Chase At that mileage you should just replace the CV axle.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+Chase That is called a cv axle. Usually the bearings in them are bad when 
they squeak so the axle needs to be replaced. How many miles on the car?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:

felt fine. no sounds (crack), when I got it aligned, it came back and now

of anything like this ? TIA﻿

the rack bolts but didn't have time for shaft and tie rods check. Thanks

comments.author: deezTX

comments.text:
+deezTX Looseness in the steering shaft and steering shaft coupling U-joint 
can cause a knocking / popping noise from the steering column when turning.

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Chris, I have a 92 Ford Taurus with 56,000 miles.  If the tie-rods  on the 
left are bad should the ones on the right be replaced at the same time?﻿
comments.author: 4ever learning

comments.text:
+4ever learning It really depends. Use this video to check that other tie 
rod. If that other tie rod feels bad or has a ripped boot, yes, replace it 
as well. If your tie rods are inexpensive, I would also consider replacing 
the other one. You dont "have" to replace them in pairs, but since you will 
need an alignment, if it is cheap enough, I would consider it. My tie rods 
lasted 120k miles in my truck and 250k miles in my van so they do last a 
long time if they are not defective or if you dont hit pot holes or curbs. 
If you do get a replacement tie rod, get one with a grease fitting.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
i replaced my inner and outer tire rod ends and bottom ball joints about 
eight months ago . bought new front tires and had a   front end 
alignment.this morning i noticed my new tires were wearing on the inside. i 
called the guy that lined it up and told him what was going on.he told me 
to bring it back and he would check it out. he puts it up on front end 
alignment machine and tell me both my bottom ball joints are bad.i told him 
i just but new ball s and inner and outer tire rod ends on it before he 
lined it up.he said i bought the cheap ball joints and there bad,hes sees 
it all the time. i let a friend check them and he said there ok.i noticed 
when i put the new tires on it it had a bounce to it.went back to tire 
store and told them about it.they said nothing was wrong,so im out 450.00 
dollars and told i got bad ball joints and m,y new tires are garbage . is 
it possible these new ball joints went bad this quick. ﻿
comments.author: marissa henson

comments.text:
+marissa henson It is possible that the new ball joints went bad that quick 
but it sounds like he is trying to stiff you...What brand parts did you 
get? Here is how to check ball joints yourself: How to check a Ball Joint 
and the alignment adjustment that needs to be done is called a camber 
adjustment. Since the inside of your tire is worn you have too much 
negative camber. If you check your ball joints and they are good, I would 
go in and tell them you had your ball joints checked and they are fine and 
you would like your camber adjusted. Let me know what you find out. What 
car is this by the way?
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: great video Chris, thanks!﻿
comments.author: Nomosowicz

comments.text: +Nomosowicz Thanks and no problem! Glad it was helpful!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris, my 00 Ranger has a strong squeak when turning and hitting bumps 
coming from the same side. I think it may be the lower ball joint? Also if 
I replace ball joints, should I go ahead and change the control arms as 
well? Id like to get an ay without an alignment. It only has 29 thousand 
miles. That's right 29k. Thanks, awesome videos btw very helpful to 
backyard mechanics !! ﻿
comments.author: cody martin

comments.text:
+cody martin Hey Cody, the ball joints are easy to replace on the Ranger. 
First, here is a video on how to tell if it is your ball joints: How to 
check a Ball Joint
It sounds like you have bad ball joints so I would replace both. The lower 
is pressed in but the upper you will need to replace the whole control arm. 
Here are videos for the lower ball joint and the upper control arm: How to 
Replace a Lower Ball Joint (short, quick version) and How to Replace a 
Control Arm (upper or lower)
and if you want to have your camber aligned you will need camber bolts: How 
to Install Camber Bolts
Make sure you get new ball joints with grease fittings and keep me updated!

comments.text:
i actually figured it out ,there was a bolt type of deal with 4 holes that 
was loose on passenger side of rack.it had 4 small holes in it so i rigged 
a tool long enough to get into one of the holes to turn it tight. no more 
leak. common problem in taurus racks, or so atleast i seen a bunch of 
people on fords forum with the same problem and fix. saved a bunch of money 
on my car insurance lol jk thanks though +ChrisFix
comments.author: matt pote

comments.text:
+matt pote That sounds like you need a new rack. If you drain the bellows 
boot and dry it up and then top off the power steering pump. How long until 
it drains out and fills the bellows boot again?

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
great videos. I was wondering if you could clarify one question. On your 
video on how to change the inner and outer tire rod you talk about 
adjusting your tork wrench to 46 when tightening the castle nut. I don't 
own one of those? do you have any suggestions. how much would it be for a 
honda civic 04?﻿
comments.author: Bidkar Salazar

comments.text: +Fix
comments.author: Nancy Cisneros

comments.text:
+Bidkar Salazar Thanks Bidkar! If you work on your car, you should get a 
decent torque wrench. It allows you to set how tight the bolts/nuts are. 
Here is a video on how to use a torque wrench: How to use a Torque Wrench
As for your Honda and the torque specs, I would check the civic forums or 
get a service manual. That is where you will find the correct torque. I am 
sure it is something similar to what it is in the video. If you tighten the 
castle nut until it is tight against the knuckle and then tighten it half 
of what you would tighten lug nuts, that is about 50ft-lbs. Make sure you 
dont back the castle nut off at all when you align the hole for the cotter 
pin.
comments.author: ChrisFix

there any clicking motion or up and down motion in the ball joint itself? 
Do you feel any resistance when you move the ball joint stud of the tie 
rod?
